title: Understanding Postcoital Bleeding
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Postcoital bleeding is bleeding that happens after vaginal sex. It is not part of your period.

items: The amount of blood can range from light spotting to heavier flow
It can happen after penetration by a penis, sex toys, or fingers
Around 1 in 10 women experience this at some point — it is common and usually not serious

items.title: Statistics
items.description: Only about 15% of women who experience it also report pain during sex

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: About 30% of women who bleed during sex also have other abnormal bleeding outside their period.

sections.buttonLabel: Where Does the Bleeding Come From?
sections.cardTitle: Where Does the Bleeding Come From?

content.value: Postcoital bleeding usually comes from the vagina or cervix
Usually from direct friction or trauma during sex — known as a vaginal laceration.

tags: May be heavier and bright red

items: The vagina is not well lubricated
Estrogen levels are low (breastfeeding or menopause)
A foreign object is used (e.g., piercings or implants)

content.title: Healing Time
content.description: Minor tears usually heal on their own in a few days to weeks. Larger tears may need stitches but heal within six weeks.

content.value: Bleeding from the cervix is usually light — often just seen when wiping.

items.title: Cervical Ectropion
items.content: Inner cervical cells turn outward and are more fragile. Common during pregnancy or when using the pill. These cells bleed easily with contact.

items.title: Cervical Polyps
items.content: Small benign growths in the cervical canal. Have a rich blood supply and bleed easily during sex.

items.title: Cervicitis
items.content: Inflammation of the cervix. Often caused by STIs like chlamydia. May have no symptoms early on but can affect fertility. Can be treated with antibiotics.

items.title: Cervical Cancer
items.content: The least common but most serious cause. Very unlikely if you have regular cervical smear tests. Needs urgent assessment and treatment.

items: Heavy bleeding (soaking pads/tampons or causing dizziness)
Bleeding after sex with pelvic pain, fever, or foul-smelling discharge

content.title: Important
content.description: Get medical help straight away if you notice these symptoms.

sections.cardTitle: What to Track Before Your Appointment

content.value: Bring this info with you — it can help your doctor find the cause quickly

items.title: Timing
items.description: When the bleeding happens (timing and cycle day)

items.title: Amount
items.description: How much blood (light spots or heavier flow)

items.title: Pain
items.description: If there's pain during or after sex

items.title: Other Symptoms
items.description: Any other symptoms (discharge, odour, pelvic pain, fever)

items.title: Lubrication
items.description: Use lubrication if vaginal dryness is an issue

items.title: Moisturiser
items.description: Try a vaginal moisturiser if post-menopausal

items.title: Be Gentle
items.description: Avoid rough or prolonged intercourse until you've been checked

items.title: Regular Screening
items.description: Keep up with regular cervical smear tests
